item.title: 4D-Net: Learning Multi-Modal Alignment for 3D and Image Inputs in Time | Google AI Blog
item.description: Posted by AJ Piergiovanni and Anelia Angelova, Research Scientists, Google Research While not immediately obvious, all of us experience the world in four dimensions (4D). For example, when walking or ...
item.content:encoded: Posted by AJ Piergiovanni and Anelia Angelova, Research Scientists, Google Research While not immediately obvious, all of us experience the world in four dimensions (4D). For example, when walking or driving down the street we observe a stream of visual inputs, snapshots of the 3D world, which, when taken together in time, creates a 4D visual input. Today‚Äôs autonomous vehicles and robots are able to capture much of this information through various onboard sensing mechanisms, such as LiDAR and ca...

item.description: The 36th AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence (AAAI 2022) is being hosted virtually from February 22th - March 1st. We‚Äôre excited to share all the work from SAIL that‚Äôs being presented, and you‚Äô...
item.content:encoded: The 36th AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence (AAAI 2022) is being hosted virtually from February 22th - March 1st. We‚Äôre excited to share all the work from SAIL that‚Äôs being presented, and you‚Äôll find links to papers, videos and blogs below. Feel free to reach out to the contact authors directly to learn more about the work that‚Äôs happening at Stanford. item.content:encoded: Posted by Ali Kemal Sinop and Kostas Kollias, Research Scientists, Google Research In the world of networks, there are models that can explain observations across a diverse collection of applications. These include simple tasks such as computing the shortest path, which has obvious applications to routing networks but also applies in biology, e.g., where the slime mold Physarum is able to find shortest paths in mazes. item.description: Posted by Daniel Suo, Software Engineer and Elad Hazan, Research Scientist, Google Research, on behalf of the Google AI Princeton Team Mechanical ventilators provide critical support for patients who ...
item.content:encoded: Posted by Daniel Suo, Software Engineer and Elad Hazan, Research Scientist, Google Research, on behalf of the Google AI Princeton Team Mechanical ventilators provide critical support for patients who have difficulty breathing or are unable to breathe on their own. They see frequent use in scenarios ranging from routine anesthesia, to neonatal intensive care and life support during the COVID-19 pandemic. A typical ventilator consists of a compressed air source, valves to control the flow of air i...

item.content:encoded: Posted by Joshua Greaves, Software Engineer and Pablo Samuel Castro, Staff Software Engineer, Google Research, Brain Team Benchmark challenges have been a driving force in the advancement of machine learning (ML). In particular, difficult benchmark environments for reinforcement learning (RL) have been crucial for the rapid progress of the field by challenging researchers to overcome increasingly difficult tasks. The Arcade Learning Environment, Mujoco, and others have been used to push the enve...

item.title: An Easy Guide to Choose the Right Machine Learning Algorithm | KDnuggets
item.description: There's no free lunch in machine learning. So, determining which algorithm to use depends on many factors from the type of problem at hand to the type of output you are looking for. This guide offers ...
item.content:encoded: There's no free lunch in machine learning. So, determining which algorithm to use depends on many factors from the type of problem at hand to the type of output you are looking for. This guide offers several considerations to review when exploring the right ML approach for your dataset.

item.title: Building a Visual Search Engine ‚Äì Part 2: The Search Engine | KDnuggets
item.description: Ever wonder how Google or Bing finds similar images to your image? The algorithms for generating text based 10 blue-links are very different from finding visually similar or related images. In this ar...
item.content:encoded: Ever wonder how Google or Bing finds similar images to your image? The algorithms for generating text based 10 blue-links are very different from finding visually similar or related images. In this article, we will explain one such method to build a visual search engine. We will use the Caltech 101 dataset which contains images of common objects used in daily life.

item.content:encoded: Posted by Po-Hsuan Cameron Chen, Software Engineer, Google Health and Maggie Demkin, Program Manager, Kaggle In recent years, machine learning (ML) competitions in health have attracted ML scientists to work together to solve challenging clinical problems. These competitions provide access to relevant data and well-defined problems where experienced data scientists come to compete for solutions and learn new methods. However, a fundamental difficulty in organizing such challenges is obtaining an...

item.title: Guiding Frozen Language Models with Learned Soft Prompts | Google AI Blog
item.description: Posted by Brian Lester, AI Resident and Noah Constant, Senior Staff Software Engineer, Google Research Large pre-trained language models, which are continuing to grow in size, achieve state-of-art res...
item.content:encoded: Posted by Brian Lester, AI Resident and Noah Constant, Senior Staff Software Engineer, Google Research Large pre-trained language models, which are continuing to grow in size, achieve state-of-art results on many natural language processing (NLP) benchmarks. Since the development of GPT and BERT, standard practice has been to fine-tune models on downstream tasks, which involves adjusting every weight in the network (i.e., model tuning). However, as models become larger, storing and serving a tun...
